headline.print_headline: California Town and Its Public Retirees Reel Under $1.6 Million Pension Bill
headline.main: $1.6 Million Bill Tests Tiny Town and ‘Bulletproof’ Public Pensions

snippet: When the hamlet of Loyalton, Calif., withdrew from the state’s pension system, it was told to pay up or its four retirees’ pensions would be slashed....
abstract: Small town of Loyalton, Calif, which severed ties with California Public Employees' Retirement System in 2013, has been informed it has one month to pay $1.6 million to fund pensions of its four retirees, amount that exceeds town's entire annual budget; state courts have previously ruled that once public employees join Calpers, employers are obligated to properly fund pension plans; some see Loyalton's dilemma as test case for cities in California and across nation with similar shortfalls in public pension funds.
